hooks_and_draws.Draw: Delivered sensitive information (roll on Knowledge Objective table)
Asked for help (roll on Religious Tenets table)
Funded an expedition (roll on Cult table)
Has mistaken a player character‚Äôs identity
Placed an artifact in a player character‚Äôs safekeeping with their final breath
Called in a debt or favor
Has information on someone relevant who is missing or dead (roll on Religious Tenets table)
Has been framed for crime or treason
Offered details on another antagonist (roll on Primary Antagonist table)

plot_concept.Motivation: Being manipulated by someone or something (roll twice on the Primary Antagonist table, with the second roll as the true antagonist)
Forbidden knowledge (roll on Knowledge Objective table)
To protect a person, place, or belief
To divert attention from the true scheme (roll again for both the real plot and motivation)

primary_antagonist.Trait: Layered quality (roll twice: first is actual, second is apparent)

plot_fulfillment_and_location.From/Where: The Island of the Black Ones
A lost island or ruin (Knowledge Objectives table)
A pyramid lost to the desert
The vault of a hidden cult (Cult table)
The hidden depths of the Maul
An otherworldly entity‚Äôs lair (Ancient or Otherworldly Creature table)
A royal vault (Ancient or Otherworldly Creature table)

obstacles_and_twists.Plot Twist: They must make a great personal sacrifice (one or more group members)
They are the experiment (a group or faction is testing their abilities)
Led into a trap (they are the antagonist‚Äôs missing ingredient)
Into the jaws of death (no one is expected to leave alive)
The antagonist is part of the group (if played right, maybe even a player character)
Intelligence leads them to believe there is only one to deal with (they were wrong!)
Familial connections (the antagonist has close ties to a player character)
Snake in the grass (a traitor working for an independent faction ‚Äî roll on Non-Player Characters table)
High body count
Damned if we do‚Ä¶ (letting the antagonist escape will save countless lives)
A person or object that is a required to foil the antagonist is also exactly what the antagonist needs!
To understand a villain, you must become the villain (they must do bad things to achieve their goal)
The antagonist is a patsy for the true villain (roll again on Primary Antagonist table)
The antagonist is performing heinous acts in the hope of preventing a greater evil
Fulfillment before their eyes (the group arrive too late or the event unfolds around them)
Cut off and left adrift (the group‚Äôs supporters fall strangely silent and no longer provide support)
A key character of the plot is killed, only to return alive later (can be keyed to entries 2 or 8 of this table)
The player characters are working for the real villain and the antagonist is trying to stop them
Tread dark paths (the player characters must open themselves to Corruption to achieve a greater good)
Escalation (roll twice on this table, ignoring further results of 20)

opponent.Otherworldly creature: 20 (Roll on Ancient or Otherworldly Creature table)

hazards.examples: The player character stands on a sharpened spike or takes a punch from behind.
A booby-trap constructed from small sharp blades; spears that spring from the walls.
A more lethal trap; a mid-sized rockslide.
A large and deadly trap; a large rockslide.
A complicated trap that fires multiple darts or stones.

hazards.doom_cost: Equal to half X, rounding up
hazards.examples: A fire spreads around the player character; the roof catches fire and starts to cave in; molten lava in close proximity.
A massive boulder; a sharpened man-trap.
A log swung at shoulder height; a small pitfall.

hazards.nonlethal: Reduce overall Doom Cost by two
hazards.examples: A sand dune collapsing on the player character; a fall onto soft ground.

hazards.doom_cost: Equal to half X, rounding up

hazards.examples: A gas stirred up by the opening of ancient doors; a trap that drops rocks.

hazards.doom_cost: Equal to half X, rounding up
hazards.examples: Long narrow blades that leave bleeding wounds.
Traps set by master trap makers.

hazard_difficulties.doom_cost: Reduce overall Doom Cost by three
hazard_difficulties.examples: A river bank with an obvious ford.

hazard_difficulties.doom_cost: Reduce overall Doom Cost by one
hazard_difficulties.examples: A river bank with no ford.

armor.armor_type: Light Armor Brigandine Sleeves or Trousers
Light Armor Brigandine Sleeve or Legging
Heavy Armor Heavy Hauberk or Coat
Heavy Armor Heavy Sleeve or Legging
Very Heavy Armor Arm or Leg Plates
Very Heavy Armor Full Plate Armor

mount_or_vehicle_hit_locations.location_struck: Animal(s): Roll for damage normally against the creature(s) pulling the vehicle.
mount_or_vehicle_hit_locations.effect: Driver: Roll for damage normally against the driver. If there is more than one driver, roll randomly to determine which is struck.
mount_or_vehicle_hit_locations.any_other_result: Vehicle: The mount or vehicle is instead struck. For mounts, damage is taken as per humans, while the gamemaster should determine the effects of damage to the vehicle.
